239.description: dark, red macule or papule, progressing into erosion, leading to a well‐circumscribed, flat ulcer with a yellow coated base and an indurated, non‐undermined wall (chancre). Most often not painful, and usually single lesion

medias.label: Primary syphilis lesion (chancre) Courtesy of atlasdermatologico.com

3371.label: Is Doxycycline available ?
3371.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

241.label: Painful swelling of groin
241.description: tender swelling of swollen lymphnodes in the groin, sometimes with a characteristic "groove sign" formed by swollen lymph nodes developing along the course of the inguinal ligament

242.label: Inguinal Bubo (painful inguinal or femoral lymph nodes)
242.description: Inguinal Bubo: Unilateral or bilateral, tender, sometimes purulent inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy. Develops 2-6 wks after painful ulcer/papules

244.label: Urethral discharge
244.description: Purulent or mucopurulent discharge from the urethra, often associated with dysuria, alguria, itching or foul odor.

246.label: Costovertebral tenderness
246.description: The costovertebral angle made by the vertebral column and the costal margin is the area of the back that overlies the kidney. Percussion of this area that causes pain is referred to as costovertebral tenderness.

250.label: Very painful menstruation
250.description: Cramps or throbbing pain in the lower abdomen/lower back during menstruation, sometimes accompanied by nausea, vomiting or fatigue.

219.label: Menarche (history of menstruation)
219.description: Ask the patient if she already had her first menstrual bleeding

2018.label: Suspicion of pregnancy?
2018.description:
Missed period and recent unprotected vaginal sex.
Note: women can have light irregular bleeding during pregnancy, but much less than their normal period.

4066.label: During this current illness has the patient already completed 3 days of antibiotic treatment for a urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis?
4066.description: If there are no improvement following three days of antibiotic treatment for urinary tract infection or pyelonephritis, referral for further investigations is warranted.

259.label: Scrotal pain
259.description: The patient reports an acute severe testicular/scrotal pain.

262.label: Testicular tenderness (suspicion of testicular torsion)
262.description: Very painful, high-riding testicle with absent cremasteric reflex, the scrotal skin can be indurated, red/dark and warm

1855.label: Severe pain or reduction of hernia not possible

1760.label: Inguinal hernia: Inguinal/groin tenderness
1760.description: Reducible inguinal swelling worse when coughing

280.label: Tender / colored abdominal bulge
280.description: A tender or colored abdominal bulge that is visible on the abdominal wall. The most common cause of the bump is a hernia (abnormal exit of tissue or organ, such as bowel, through the abdominal wall), the tenderness and/or discoloration is a sign of possible incarceration (hernial content is trapped, leading eventually to blood circulation disorder and necrosis).

282.label: Severe abdominal palpation (needing referral)
282.description:
Select this as "present" if the abdominal palpation is of great concern, for which the child should be referred for further investigations (US, surgical evaluation).
To examine the abdomen, the child should be in supine position (on his/her back) and the abdominal wall muscles need to be relaxed. Examine the abdomen from the right side. Ask the child to point to the area of greatest pain, examine this point last. Divide the abdomen in 4 quadrants (upper left, lower left, upper right, lower right) and examine each quadrant. To palpate the abdomen, place the flat of your hand on the abdominal wall and apply a firm and steady pressure. Observe the child's facial expression during palpation to determine if they are in pain. For younger children who refuse to lay on his/her back or crying infants, examine the abdomen while the child is sitting on the mother's lap. Check for guarding (=contraction of the abdominal wall muscle to avoid pain during palpation) and for rebound tenderness (=tenderness by quickly removing the examining hand after palpation) 
Signs of severe abdominal palpation include: Rebound tenderness. Pain to even light touch.

Signs of appendicitis include : Right lower quadrant tenderness or rebound tenderness, accentuated when jumping on right foot, pain migrating from the umbilical region to the right lower quadrant over hours or days associated with fever and/or diarrhea and/or loss of appetite 

Signs of severe abdominal palpation include: Diffuse rebound tenderness. Pain to even light touch.

Specific signs of appendicitis include : Right lower quadrant tenderness or rebound tenderness, accentuated when jumping on right foot, pain migrating from the umbilical region associated with fever.

279.label: Bilious vomit
279.description: Grass-green to dark-green vomit. Bilious vomit contains bile and can be a symptom of intestinal obstruction or Ileus.

1705.label: Suspicion of severe gastrointestinal bleeding (excessive blood in stool or vomit)
1705.description:
Gastrointestinal bleeding can present as blood in stool or vomit.

Blood in stool: Severe gastrointestinal bleeding can occur in the case of intestinal obstruction (intussusception) in which the child most often presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, lethargic, and bloody stools (like "currant jelly"). 

Blood in vomit: Severe gastrointestinal bleeding, presents as large quantity of blood in the vomit and can be due to rupture of esophageal varices, or injury of the esophagus from a foreign object (less commonly gastritis).

Note, not all blood in stool or vomit is gastro-intestinal bleeding, and it is not always severe. Other causes include dysentery, milk or soy induced colitis, anal fissures, epistaxis, or ingesting food that resembles blood.

3372.label: Are oral Ciprofloxacine and oral Metronidazole available ?
3372.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

4060.label: Return visit for dysentery after 3 days of treatment with ciprofloxacine?

4062.label: Number of stools, amount of blood in stools, fever, abdominal pain, or eating are worse or the same?
4062.description: Criteria to identify patients with persisting dysentery in need of a modification in the antibiotic treatment or possibly referral.

2079.label: Currently treated with Ready to use therapeutic food (RUTF)

4592.label: Evolution of white patches, ulcers or white plaques in the mouth

2116.label: Is the infant feeding well currently?
2116.description: Maternal report. That is, are they feeding well, not feeding well or not feeding at all?

2162.label: Difficulty in the feeding process (either breast or bottle/cup feeding)
2162.description: That is, the infant is demanding feedings but the latching or attachment or sucking is a challenge or they seem unable to get sufficient feeds.

2064.label: Vitamin A in the past month, or already on Read To Use Therapeutic Food

4057.label: Has this patient already been given zinc for 5 or more days along with feeding counselling for persistent diarrhea?
4057.description: If a child with persistent diarrhea returns for an unscheduled or scheduled follow-up visit with persisting diarrhea despite feeding counseling and zinc for 5 or more days, referral is warranted.

255.label: Worms in stool
255.description: Ask if the caregiver or patient if they have ever seen worms in the stools or in the anal region of the child over the past week.

3285.label: Is Albendazole available?
3285.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

4598.label: Reported joint swelling?
4598.description: Did the caretaker or patient report that a joint is swollen (enlarged)?

309.label: Duration of joint pain or limp
309.description: How long has the patient had this joint pain or limp?

308.label: History of fall or trauma
308.description: Did the child fall, or was the child in an accident, or was the child hit by something that could explain the pain?

3525.label: Is parenteral Amoxicillin / Clavulanic acid (IV/IM) available?

311.label: Wound infection (pus, warmth, or swelling)
311.description: Surrounding skin inflammed, red, warm, pus, or swelling

2028.label: Persisting fever or no improvement of wound and surrounding skin after > 72 hours of antibiotics?

446.label: Vaccinations incomplete for age?
446.description: Ask to see the child's vaccination card / Child Health card (Kadi ya kliniki ya mtoto): See if vaccinations are up to date for their age.

3355.label: Bite wound
3355.description: Bite or suspicion of bite from human or animal

2030.label: Suture conditions (clean wound < 24h, dirty wound < 6 h)

2033.label: Complicated deep wound needing referral (>5% TBSA, motor deficit, signs of severe infection)

3491.label: Uncontrolled bleeding
3491.description: There is bleeding that does not stop.

2984.label: Severe pain, deformation, loss of motricity or feeling

321.label: Suspicion of bone fracture or dislocation

3528.label: Contusion with severe deformity, unable to weightbear, or loss of motricity/feeling
3528.description: If there is severe deformity or the child is unable to weightbear or loss of motricity/feeling due to major soft tissue injury, and fracture was not identified, click yes, and the child will be referred for a specialized outpatient consultation.

325.label: Burn injury
325.description: Has the child suffered a burn resulting in skin breakdown? (adapted from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020)

2987.label: Skin warm or swollen or with pus
2987.description: Surrounding skin inflamed, red, warm, pus, swelling

328.label: Burn circumferential
328.description: Circumferential burns, are full thickness burns that go around a finger, arm, leg, or even torso. This blocks the circulation and is dangerous.

326.label: Burn size
326.description: The general rule is, the size of the patient's palm is equivalent to 1% of his/her total body surface area (TBSA). See figure for TBSA of other body parts.

547.label: < 5% of total body surface area (1% = hand palm)

2182.label: Is Mupirocin cream 2% available?
2182.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

341.label: Signs of basilar skull fracture
341.description: Retro-auricular/periorbital bruising, blood or CSF runningfrom ear

334.label: Altered mental status
334.description: Altered mental status (agitation, somnolence, repetitive questioning, or slow response to verbal communication)

340.label: Open skull fracture
340.description: Open skull fracture or compound fracture is when there is a fracture of the skull (splintering of the skull bone) and a break in the skin.

335.label: History of loss of consciousness
335.description: At the moment of the accident did the child loose consciousness (interruption of awareness and no response to people or other environmental stimuli).

332.label: Head struck by a high-impact object

344.label: Major trauma (car accident, suspicion of multiple fractures, major bleeding)
344.description: Pedestrian hit by fast moving car, pedestrian run over by car, passenger in car accident in fast moving car, major fall, or other major trauma resulting in suspicion of multiple fractures, or major bleeding.

347.label: Significant exposure to fire or smoke

2988.label: Wheezing
2988.description: Wheezing is a high-pitched, whistling sound a child makes when breathing, especially when exhaling. It happens when the airways are tightened, or inflamed, often in the case of reactive airway disease (asthma).

3531.label: Is Oxygen therapy available in this health facility?

354.label: Severe irritability
354.description: Has the child been crying throughout the interview, even before you approached him/her? Is the child inconsolable by the caretaker? (Adapted from Pediatric Sepsis CoLab 2020)

357.label: Accidental ingestion of potentially harmful entity

361.label: Large area of warm, pink and tender skin around abscess

2052.label: Drainage of abscess possible at this health facility?
2052.description: Does your health facility have the capacity to perform abscess drainage today?

369.label: Improvement of cellulitis after 3 days of antibiotic treatment?

4603.label: Did the patient already receive 3 days of antibiotics for cellulitis?

9.label: Respiratory rate in percentile
9.description:
Respiratory rate percentiles based on age and body temperature 
(REF: Nijman et al., BMJ 2012)
9.max_message_warning: The respiratory rate you have entered is well above the expected respiratory rate. This may be a sign of respiratory distress which would result in referring the child for inpatient admission. Please double check this value, or count the respiratory rate once again over 60 seconds.

384.label: Oral herpes
384.description: Single or grouped vesicles often around mouth. Often painful.

387.label: Tinea corporis
387.description: Often itchy circular or oval red scaling patch or plaque. At later stages central clearing occurs, with spread of raised borders. It is sometimes surrounded by vesicles.

2263.label: Is oral Griseofulvin available ?
2263.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

2183.label: Is Benzoic acid compound (whitfield) 6% + 3% ointment availale?
2183.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

390.label: Tinea capitis
390.description: Often itchy circular or oval red scaling patch or plaque.  At later stages central clearing occurs, with spread of raised borders. Sometimes surrounded by vesicles, pustule formations or a buggy fluctuant mass (kerion). It is often associated with hair loss.

392.label: Scabies
392.description:
Itchy (especially at night), small, pink or flesh coloured or dark papules or vesicles, or pustules sometimes with excoriation or burrows. Found mostly in interdigital spaces of the hands and feet, wrists, waistline, and genitals. In infants consider palms and soles.

If household members also have a similar itchy rash, this diagnosis is more likely.

medias.label: Scabies 2 Courtesy of Dr. Usatine, dermatlas.net
Scabies 4 Courtesy of Prof. Karim Manji, Muhimbili University of Health and Allied Sciences [Muhimbili National Hospital approval reference number MNH/LA.69/233/01/23

394.label: Urticaria
394.description:
Urticaria (hives) are slightly raised, flesh colored patches of the skin. They occur in groups on any part of the body and can look like mosquito bites. They are often very itchy especially at night. 
Hives are very common and usually caused by an allergic reaction, by chemicals in foods, medicines and plants or by a viral infection. This leads to a release of a chemical called histamine. Often, urticaria is caused by multiple triggers rather than one single cause.

4602.label: Anaphylaxis
4602.description:
Anaphylaxis is a serious allergic reaction that progresses fast and may cause death, after contact with an allergy-causing substance.

Most cases of anaphylaxis have a skin rash (urticaria, itching, flushing) or involvement of mucosal tissue. They can be associated with respiratory symptoms (difficulty breathing, wheeze, stridor), and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms (crampy abdominal pain, vomiting).

REF: Second symposium on the definition and management of anaphylaxis (Sampson et al. 2006)

3375.label: Is oral Chlorpheniramine available ?
3375.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

397.label: Atopic eczema
397.description:
in infants: Itchy, red/pink (sometimes hypo or hyperpigmentation especially on dark skin), scaly and crusted lesions on cheek, forehead, scalp, or extensor surfaces. Rarely in groin and axilla region.
 in children: Itchy, thick (lichenified) plaques (sometimes hypo or hyperpigmentation especially on dark skin) in flexural surfaces especially elbows, knees, neck, wrist and ankles. Rarely in groin and axilla region.

medias.label: Atopic eczema 2 Courtesy of Dr. Usatine, dermatlas.net
Atopic eczema 3 Courtesy of Dr. Usatine, dermatlas.net

3376.label: Is Betamethasone cream available ?
3376.description: Note if both first and second line treatments are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

399.label: Pityriasis versicolor
399.description: Hypo/hyperpigmented patches (most often on chest, back and arms). Not itchy.

1704.label: Deep or extensive mouth ulcers
1704.description: In severe cases, they are deep and extensive. Select this option if a child with measles has mouth ulcers which makes it difficult to drink or eat, thus needing admission/referral.

3505.label: Pus is draining from the eye?
3505.description: Pus (white-yellow-green discharge) draining  from  the  eye  is  a  sign  of  conjunctivitis.  Conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva, the inside surface of the eyelid and the white part of the eye. If you do not see pus draining from the eye, look for pus on the conjunctiva or on the eyelids. Often the pus forms a crust when the child is sleeping and seals the eye shut. You can gently open the eye, making sure that your hands are clean. Wash your hands after examining the eye of any child with pus draining from the eye.

4532.label: Clouding of the cornea
4532.description:
The cornea is the part of the eye that covers the colored part; it is usually clear. When clouding of the cornea is present, the cornea may appear clouded or hazy. The cornea may look the way a glass of water looks when you add a small amount of milk. The clouding may occur in one or both eyes. 
Corneal clouding is a dangerous condition. It may be the result of vitamin A deficiency that has been made worse by measles. If the corneal clouding is not treated, the cornea can ulcerate and cause blindness. 
A child with clouding of the cornea needs urgent treatment with vitamin A. A  child  with  corneal  clouding  may  keep  his  or  her  eyes  tightly  shut  when  exposed  to  light.  The  light  may  cause  irritation and pain to the child’s eyes. To check the child’s eye, wait for the child to open his or her eye. Or gently pull down the lower eyelid to look for clouding.
If there is clouding of the cornea, ask the caregiver how long the clouding has been present. If the caregiver is certain that clouding has been there for some time, ask if the clouding has already been assessed and treated at the hospital. If it has, you do not need to refer this child again for corneal clouding.
REF IMCI 2014

4534.label: Mouth ulcer
4534.description:
Look inside the child’s mouth for mouth ulcers. Ulcers are painful open sores on the inside of the mouth and lips or the tongue. They may be red or have white coating.

In patients with measles, note that mouth ulcers are different than the small spots called Koplik spots. Koplik spots occur in the mouth inside the cheek during early stages of the measles infection. Koplik spots are small, irregular, bright red spots with a white spot in the centre. They do not interfere with drinking or eating. They do not need treatment.

452.label: Last vitamin A supplementation
452.description: Ask to see the child's Child Health card (Kadi ya kliniki ya mtoto): See if vitamin A supplementation is up to date.

3250.label: Age 6m to 10y for very low WFA

3465.label: Did the infant previously feed well, and then stop feeding?

3464.label: Is the infant demanding or attempting feeds?

3444.label: How is the infant feeding currently?
3444.description:
Not feeding well: Feeding less than usual. Accepting some feeds when offered.
Not feeding at all: Refusing feeds when offered. Does not demand feeds at all. Does not feed at all.

2117.label: Severe chest indrawing
2117.description: Observed. Must be when infant is calm. Severe chest indrawing indicates the lower chest wall is indrawn on inhalation.

2115.label: Observation of movement
2115.description: On observation. Young infant must be awake. If the infant is sleeping, gently wake him or her.

2968.label: Yellow appearing skin started <24 hours of life

2131.label: Estimated birth weight (records not available)
2131.description: If birth weight not documented in records. Maternal report.

2129.label: Estimated gestational age
2129.description: If gestational age not documented/known from record book. Maternal report

4520.label: Gestational age at delivery from records (weeks)

2993.label: Bruising and/or oedema of the genitals

2992.label: Bruising and/or petechiae (pinpoint size bleeding spots) present anywhere on body (common on head, face)

2998.label: History of fall or postnatal trauma

3486.label: Bruising and/or oedema present within 24 hours of birth?

3003.label: Tilting of the head to one side and neck rotation with the chin pointing to the opposite side
3003.description: The infant usually has a preferred position of the head. Often associated with limited range of motion of the neck.

3490.label: Abnormal positioning of the head and neck

3172.label: Split in the lip on one or both sides of mouth (Cleft lip)

medias.label: Cleft Lip, From pocket book of hospital care for children: guidelines for the management of common illnesses with limited resources, 2nd edition, world health organisation, page 235, Copyright (2013)

3173.label: Cleft palate (Split or opening in the roof of one or both sides of the mouth)

medias.label: Cleft palate, from pocket book of hospital care for children: guidelines for the management of common illnesses with limited resources, 2nd edition, world health organisation, page 235, Copyright (2013)

3178.label: Odd looking, unusual or abnormal appearance

3481.label: Extra or missing fingers or toes

3468.label: Is the infant receiving any breast milk?

3469.label: Observe breastfeeding: Attaching well to breast?

3230.label: Report of problem in producing sufficient milk supply

3231.label: Sufficient amount of food given at each feed?

5112.label: Number of times infant usually feeds in one day and night

3014.label: Diarrhea (stools are looser or more watery than normal)

3472.label: Infant given any other food or fluid besides breastmilk?
3472.description: Other food or fluid besides breastmilk include formula, cow's milk, goat's milk, water, porridge, etc.

2107.label: Concern for not gaining weight, or losing weight

4616.label: Weight less than previous consultation (review of child health records if available)

3474.label: Observe breastfeeding: Does the infant tire quickly or sweat?

4526.label: Is the infant worse than when they first consulted?

4525.label: Was the previous consultation for pneumonia or severe pneumonia?

5115.label: Is the infant being referred to another health facility for another condition?

4607.label: Infant vomiting everything ?
4607.description: Does the infant vomit every time he/she feeds?

439.label: Child tested for HIV in the past?
439.description: Has the patient ever had an HIV test?

5116.label: Is the patient followed at an HIV care and treatment centre?

5095.label: Are Cloxacillin and Gentamicin IM available ?
5095.description: Note if both first and second line treatment are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

5096.label: Is Ampiclox IM available ?
5096.description: Note if both first and second line treatment are unavailable, the first line treatment will be proposed and the patient will have to seek it outside of the health facility.

5098.label: Pustules or blisters located in 2 or more areas of the body

3294.label: Skin blisters (any size, with clear liquid or with pus)

3295.label: Sloughing / peeling of skin (resembling burned skin )

3552.label: Capacity/skill available to incise and drain at the clinic

3318.label: Mongolian spots (Blue, black, grey or dark green flat spots)
3318.description: Present from birth, not painful, not raised or swollen.

3317.label: Heat rash: Red papules 2-4 mm on a red rash

3315.label: Heat rash: Very small, raised white or clear spots (rain drops)
3315.description:
Young Infants:
Raised spots most often 1-2mm.
Found most often on the head, neck and upper trunk.

3313.label: Erythema toxicum: Numerous small red or pink spots with small white raised spots in the middle
3313.description:
Multiple small red spots (1 to 3 mm in diameter) that rapidly progress to pustules (white raised spots) on a red base. Lesions are most often found on the trunk and upper arms/legs, and are not found on palms and soles. 
They can be present at birth but often appear within 24 to 48 hours. 
REF: Mathes et al. 2018

3461.label: Red eye
3461.description: Redness in the white part of the eye.

3463.label: Substantial purulent eye discharge
3463.description: Purulent discharge re-accumulates shortly after wiping the eye.

4594.label: Is the redness or swelling in the eye better, the same or worse than at the previous consultation?

4593.label: Previous diagnosis conjunctivitis or neonatal conjunctivitis

3548.label: Appetite test unavailable: Is the child eating well at home?
3548.description: Child eating well at home: able to finish at least three teaspoons of food.

3487.label: Appetite test
3487.description:
Provide Ready-to-Use Therapeutic Food (RUTF) or equivalent to eat at the consultation:
    FAIL: The child fails the appetite test, he/she cannot finish the RUTF portion or equivalent
    PASS: The child passes the appetite test, he/she can finish the RUTF portion or equivalent
    Child too sick to perform test: If the child is too sick to perform the test, it will be considered equivalent to failing the test.
    Not available: RUTF or equivalent is not available, considered as pass

2866.label: Child too sick to perform test

140.label: Clouding of the cornea
140.description:
The cornea is the part of the eye that covers the colored part; it is usually clear. When clouding of the cornea is present, the cornea may appear white clouded or hazy. The cornea may look the way a glass of water looks when you add a small amount of milk. The clouding may occur in one or both eyes. 
Corneal clouding is a dangerous condition. It may be the result of vitamin A deficiency that has been made worse by measles. If the corneal clouding is not treated, the cornea can ulcerate and cause blindness. 
A child with clouding of the cornea needs urgent treatment with vitamin A. A  child  with  corneal  clouding  may  keep  his  or  her  eyes  tightly  shut  when  exposed  to  light.  The  light  may  cause  irritation and pain to the child’s eyes. To check the child’s eye, wait for the child to open his or her eye. Or gently pull down the lower eyelid to look for clouding.
If there is clouding of the cornea, ask the caregiver how long the clouding has been present. If the caregiver is certain that clouding has been there for some time, ask if the clouding has already been assessed and treated at the hospital. If it has, you do not need to refer this child again for corneal clouding.
REF IMCI 2014

144.label: In-turned eye lashes
144.description: Eyelashes grow toward the eye, with at least one eyelash rubbing on the eyeball

3819.label: Widal test
3819.description: Of note, the widal test is not very reliable as the sensitivity and specificity of the test is very low. Many children without Typhoid fever may have a positive test, and many children with Typhoid fever may have a negative test.

4041.label: Did the patient eat or drink (not including water) in the last 8 hours?
4041.description: This question is to help interpret the blood glucose, in order todetermine if the patient is fasting or not.

4550.label: Previous diagnosis diarrhea (with no dehydration or some/moderate dehydration)

4559.label: Previous diagnosis of local skin infection

4560.label: Skin pustules, since the previous consultation, are:

4564.label: Redness and/or pus around the umbilicus, since the previous consultation, is:

4574.label: Previous diagnosis concern for poor feeding, weight loss or poor weight gain

4572.label: Previous diagnosis low weight for age

4571.label: Do you (health worker) believe that feeding will improve ?

4575.label: Caregiver reports weight is less than at previous consultation/ infant is losing weight

4578.label: Review the child's growth booklet for the record if available and see if current weight less than weight at previous consultation

2065.label: Molluscum contagiosum guidance
2065.description:
-	Molluscum contagiosum is a self limiting disease, so should resolve on its own
-	Avoid scratching or touching the bumps, as this may spread the bumps to other parts of the body, or to others
-	Try to cover the bumps to avoid contact of the bumps to others
-	Do not share towels or clothes, and do not bathe the child with other children

1660.label: Paracetamol po
1660.description:
For Pain or fever
- Weight based dosing: 80mg/Kg/day (40-100 mg/Kg/day); max daily dose: 4000mg

formulations.dispensing_description: As needed for pain or fever
As needed for pain or fever

1812.label: Ensure adequate fluid and calorie intake
1812.description:
"The child may be eating much less, or eating different foods during illness. Children often lose their appetite during illness. However, they should still be encouraged to eat the types of food recommended for their age, as often as recommended, even if they do not eat much. They should be offered their favourite nutritious foods, if possible, to encourage eating. Offer small feedings frequently. After illness, good feeding helps make up for any weight loss and prevent malnutrition.

During illness an infant or young child loses fluid due to fever, fast breathing, or diarrhoea. The child will feel better and stay stronger if he or she drinks extra fluid to prevent dehydration. Frequent breastfeeding will give the infant nourishment and help prevent dehydration. (IMCI Handbook)"

2066.label: Non specific viral rash guidance
2066.description:
-	Many viruses cause a maculo-papular rash, they can be accompanied with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, headache, muscle, joint or back pain.
-	Differential diagnosis include: Erythema infectiosum, Roseola infantum, Infectious mononucleosis, dengue, chikungunya, Zika
- A definitive diagnosis requires laboratory tests that are often not available outside of hospitals, so the diagnosis is usually presumptive.
- Treatment is usually supportive, antibiotics are not useful for viral diseases

**If the diagnosis is not clear, return to the complaint categories to select "Fever without source" (if not already selected)

formulations.dispensing_description: Apply to dry hair for 10-minutes and then rinse off with warm water. Perform second application 1 week apart

Apply to dry hair for 8 to 12 hours before washing off with a nonmedicated shampoo. The hair should be left uncovered, and heat sources should not be used to dry the hair. Perform second application 1 week apart

1769.label: No inpatient referral needed: Reasons to return to clinic
1769.description:
No inpatient referral is needed.
The patient may however need an outpatient referral for another diagnosis.

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

(adapted from IMCI 2014, based on studies from Kallander et al. PLoS Med, 2018; and Mullany et al. PLoS Med, 2018)

2057.label: Scabies and lice household management advice
2057.description:
-	In the case of scabies: Treat whole family and close contacts simultaneously regardless of presence of absence of itching 
-	Moisture the skin with hydrating cream daily after initial treatment 
-	In the case of head lice: treat family members if infested (examine each household member)
-	Advise patients to bathe and dress in clean clothing
-	Boil clothes and bed linen for 10 minutes followed by ironing; soaking brushes, combs and hair ornaments in hot water for 10 minutes. 
-	any  bedding, clothing, or towels that cannot be washed should be placed in a sealed plastic bag for at least 3 days.

1771.label: Potassium permanganate solution 1:4000 (0.025%)

formulations.dispensing_description: Wet dressing with weak Potassium Permanganate soaks. Leave wet dressing for 15 to 20 minutes. Potassium permanganate solution should always be prepared fresh, as it is rapidly inactivated after being diluted.
Apply on affected area every 6 hours until the rash disappears, then continue for another 7 days.

1825.label: Prevent low blood sugar
1825.description:
"If the child is able to breastfeed:
Ask the mother to breastfeed the child.
If the child is not able to breastfeed but is able to swallow:
Give expressed breast milk or a breast-milk substitute.
If neither of these is available, give sugar water*.
Give 30 - 50 ml of milk or sugar water* before departure.
If the child is not able to swallow:
Give 50 ml of milk or sugar water* by nasogastric tube.
If no nasogastric tube available, give 1 teaspoon of sugar moistened with 1-2 drops of water sublingually and repeat doses every 20 minutes to prevent relapse.
* To make sugar water: Dissolve 4 level teaspoons of sugar (20 grams) in a 200-ml cup of clean water. (IMCI 2014)"

1808.label: Refer urgently for inpatient management
1808.description: Refer urgently with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

2072.label: Simple febrile convulsion counseling
2072.description:
-	Reassure caretaker, simple febrile convulsions are frequent (1 in 30 children), and it can happen again in 1 out of 3 children
-	There is no prevention 
-	During a seizure: try to be calm. Do not put anything (including the mothers fingers) in the child's mouth. The child will not choke or swallow the tongue. Place your child on a soft surface. Time how long the seizure lasts, if possible
-	Febrile seizures are not harmful and most children do not have any long-term health problems. They will normally grow out of them by the age of six. 
-	If the next seizure lasts long (> 5 min.) or the child does not wake up or looks very sick when the seizure stops, bring the child to a healthcare facility  

REF: Adapted from Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne fact sheets

2023.label: PLAN A: Home rehydration (Give ORS at home)
2023.description:
-	Tell the mother to give extra fluid 
-	Breastfeed frequently and for longer at each feed
-	If the child is exclusively breastfed, give ORS or clean water in addition to breast milk 
-	If the child is not exclusively breastfed, give one or more of the following: ORS Solution, food-based fluids (such as soup, rice water, yoghurt drinks) or clean water
-	when the child cannot return to a clinic if the diarrhea gets worse, it is especially important to give ORS at home 
-	Give the mother at least 2 packets of ORS to use at home
-	Give additional fluid

QUANTITY to give:
-	2m-2y: 50-100ml after each loose stool
-	> 2y: 100-200ml after each loose stool

-	Give frequent small sips from a cup (or a spoon)
-	If the child vomits, wait 10 min. Then continue, but more slowly
-	Continue giving extra fluid until diarrhea stops 
-	Continue feeding (exclusive breastfeeding if age less than 6 months)
REF IMCI 2014

Click on photo below for IMCI guidance

medias.label: Plan A: Treat Diarrhoea at home instructions

1815.label: Cough or cold or upper respiratory tract infection: Symptomatic care
1815.description:
-           Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, such as tea with lemon, lime, or honey.
-       Drink fluids: Fluids keep the throat moist and prevent dehydration.
-       Clear secretions from child using a cloth soaked in water that has been twisted to form a pointed wick
(Adapted from IMCI 2014, and Mayo Clinic 2020)

1857.label: Possible HIV guidance
1857.description:
The HIV test is positive, this does not necessarily mean the child has HIV. It could be a false positive. Follow the institution procedures to confirm the HIV status.

If the test is confirmed as positive or if the child is less than 18 months, refer to the appropriate HIV outpatient centre (care and treatment centre [CTC]).

1858.label: Negative HIV test  - Post test counselling
1858.description:
"The HIV test is negative, if the patient has had unprotected sex in the past 3 months, this may be a false negative, and should therefor be proposed a subsequent test in 3 months. 

Counsel patient on HIV transmission pathways and notably on safe sex (if appropriate age)

3538.label: Negative HIV test - Post test counselling if child is being breastfed
3538.description: If the child is still being breastfed, he/she may still be at risk of HIV. Repeat test once breastfeeding has been discontinued for more than 6 weeks.

2980.label: HIV screening counseling
2980.description:
If the HIV test is not available, propose to visit another health facility, or come back to this health facility when new HIV tests are available.

Counsel patient on HIV transmission pathways and notably on safe sex (if appropriate age)

3501.label: Ceftriaxone IV/IM
3501.description:
Antibiotic for non CNS infections
Dosage: 50mg/kg/day max 2g/day

3352.label: Trial of salbutamol inhaler
3352.description: Attempt trial of salbutamol inhaler if presence of wheezing or suspicion of reactive airway disease without delay in other treatment.

3354.label: Oxygen therapy if SpO2 <90%
3354.description:
Give oxygen through nasal prongs or a nasal catheter. 

Start oxygen flow rate to reach SpO2 of >/=94% at:
0.5 – 1L/min for neonates
1-2 L/min for infants
2-4 L/min for older children
>4 L/min if via face mask

1811.label: Croup counselling
1811.description:
-	Croup often begins without warning in the middle of the night
-	In case of subsequent episode: 
-	keep your child calm, as breathing is often more difficult when upset. The more the child is distressed, the worse their symptoms can become. 
-	If your child is irritable and feverish, give a paracetamol
-	Bring the child outside for fresh-cold air 
-	Go to a healthcare facility if symptoms are getting worse, if the child is struggling to breathe, looks very sick, becomes pale and drowsy or the lips are blue in color
REF: Adapted from Royal Children's Hospital Melbourne fact sheets

4046.label: Explain why oral antibiotics are not useful for this patient
4046.description:
The diagnosis of the patient does not require antibiotics because it is very likely not bacterial and/or often resolves without any medication. Antibiotics are not useful for viral infections, they are only useful for bacterial infections.

Giving an antibiotic for a viral illness or any illness not caused by bacteria is not good for the patient and may make the child more sick due to adverse effects of the antibiotics (diarrhea, rash, upset stomach). In the long run if children are exposed to antibiotics too many times when not needed, antibiotic resistance may develop. This means that antibiotics may not work when they are really needed. 
Reassure the patient and caretaker that antibiotics are not needed, and remind them of when to return to consultation if the child presents new symptoms, or does not get better.

1733.label: Prednisolone po
1733.description:
Steroids for severe croup
Weight based dosage 1 mg/Kg/days

1734.label: Budesonide INH
1734.description: Inhalators for reactive airway disease (asthma) or inhalation injury with wheeze

formulations.dispensing_description:
USE OF A SPACER*
A spacer is a way of delivering the bronchodilator drugs effectively into the lungs. No child under 5 years should be given an inhaler without a spacer. A spacer works as well as a nebuliser if correctly used.
 

Spacers can be made in the following way:
Use a 500ml drink bottle or similar.
Cut a hole in the bottle base in the same shape as the mouthpiece of the inhaler.
This can be done using a sharp knife.
Cut the bottle between the upper quarter and the lower 3/4 and disregard the upper quarter of the bottle.
Cut a small V in the border of the large open part of the bottle to fit to the child's nose and be used as a mask.
Flame the edge of the cut bottle with a candle or a lighter to soften it.
In a small baby, a mask can be made by making a similar hole in a plastic (not polystyrene) cup.
Alternatively commercial spacers can be used if available.
To use an inhaler with a spacer:
Remove the inhaler cap. Shake the inhaler well.
Insert mouthpiece of the inhaler through the hole in the bottle or plastic cup.
The child should put the opening of the bottle into his mouth and breath in and out through the mouth.
A carer then presses down the inhaler and sprays into the bottle while the child continues to breath normally.
Wait for three to four breaths and repeat.

For younger children place the cup over the child's mouth and use as a spacer in the same way.
* If a spacer is being used for the first time, it should be primed by 4-5 extra puffs from the inhaler.

3772.description: If the patient has presented many episodes of reactive airway disease, he/she should be assessed for asthma.

1818.label: Conjunctivitis guidance
1818.description:
-	Cold compresses: fill a bowl with cold water or with ice and water, submerge a clean towel or washcloth into the bowl and then wring it out. Apply it on the eye for 10-20 min, repeat after 2h
-	Advice about high contagiosity, importance of hand hygiene for patient and family members

1765.label: Sodium Chromoglycate 2-4% eye drops
1765.description:
Anti-inflammatory eye drops for conjunctivitis
Dosage based on Age; For 4 - 12 years : 1 drop q6h

formulations.dispensing_description: Apply 1-2 drop in the affected eye 4 times a day
Apply one drop every 3 hours to the affected eye
1 drop per affected eye every 3 hours

1821.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Ophtalmology
1821.description: Refer for specialized outpatient management at a hospital with expertise in ophthalmology.

1820.label: Foreign body removal from the eye
1820.description:
-	Pull down the lower eyelid to see the lower conjunctiva
-	Always check for a foreign body also by everting the upper eyelid (place a cotton swab on the upper eyelid of the closed eye, grasp the eyelashes with your thumb and forefinger and evert the eyelid by using the cotton swab as a fulcrum) 
-	For a visible object, try to trap it with a cotton swab. If the object persists, flush it out by flowing clean water as you hold the eyelid open
-	If many fragments are visible (f.ex. grains of sand), pour a glass of clean, warm water into the eye by holding the child's face up (one person holds the eyelid open, one person pours the water)
-	Avoid removing large, deep or central corneal foreign bodies, refer these

1827.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Dentist
1827.description:
Refer for specialized outpatient management with a dentist
If unable to incise and drain and fever or difficulty eating / drinking, urgent referral
If no abscess seen, but tooth pain and fever, urgent referral

1830.label: Dry the ear by wicking (if ear discharge present)
1830.description:
Dry the ear at least 3 times daily.
Roll clean absorbent cloth or soft, strong tissue paper into a wick.
Place the wick in the child's ear.
Remove the wick when wet.
Replace the wick with a clean one and repeat these steps until the ear is dry.
Do not put anything else in ear.
(Adapted from IMCI 2014)

1831.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Ear, nose, and throat
1831.description: Refer to health facility with expertise with ear problems including hearing loss, and extraction of foreign body in ear.

formulations.dispensing_description:
- Wash hands.
- Wash the child's mouth with clean soft cloth wrapped around the finger and wet with salt water.
- Paint the mouth with half-strength gentian violet (0.25% dilution).
- Wash hands again.
- Continue using GV for 48 hours after the ulcers have been cured.

1834.label: Oral aphtous ulcer advice
1834.description:
Oral aphthous ulcers and herpangina usually resolve on its own. These are things that could help:

-       Drink a lot of water
-       Rinse mouth with a mixture of water and salt or cold black tea  2-3x/day
-       Avoid spicy or very hot foods/beverages
-       Brush your teeth gently

1762.description:

1836.description: If lesion on breast (flaky or shiny) or painful breastfeeding, advise mother to treat with topical miconazole 2%

4581.label: Home care for jaundice. Reassure the mother the jaundice is not dangerous and will continue to diminish.

4582.label: Follow up at 3 weeks of life if jaundice is not improved.

4584.label: Follow up jaundice (follow-up in one day)

1737.label: Artesunate IV/IM
1737.description:
Pre-referral anti-Malarial for severe malaria
Weight	based dosage: 	2.4mg/kg/day

formulations.injection_instructions:
"NOTE: Injectable 60mg artesunate has two-step dilutions.
Step 1: The powder for injections should be diluted with 1 mL of 5% sodium
bicarbonate and shaken vigorously 2–3 minutes till the solution becomes clear.
Step 2: For IM injection, add 2mL of 5% dextrose or normal saline to obtain artesunate concentration of 20mg/mL. Total volume of vial for IM injection: 3mL
formulations.dispensing_description: Give first dose of artesunate intramuscular injection slowly and refer to the hospital. If you are unable to refer for hospitalization, repeat dose after 12 hrs and daily until the child can take orally. Give full dose of oral antimalarial as soon as the child is able to take orally.

formulations.injection_instructions:
"NOTE: Injectable 120mg artesunate has two-step dilutions.
Step 1: The powder for injections should be diluted with 2 mL of 5% sodium
bicarbonate and shaken vigorously 2–3 minutes till the solution becomes clear.
Step 2: For IM injection, add 4mL of 5% dextrose or normal saline to obtain artesunate concentration of 20 mg/mL.
formulations.dispensing_description: Give first dose of artesunate intramuscular injection slowly and refer to the hospital. If you are unable to refer for hospitalization, repeat dose after 12 hrs and daily until the child can take orally. Give full dose of oral antimalarial as soon as the child is able to take orally.

formulations.injection_instructions:
"NOTE: Injectable 120mg artesunate has two-step dilutions.
Step 1: The powder for injections should be diluted with 2 mL of 5% sodium
bicarbonate and shaken vigorously 2–3 minutes till the solution becomes clear.
Step 2: For IV infusion (3–4 minutes), add 10 mL of 5% dextrose or normal
saline to obtain artesunate concentration of 10 mg/mL. (Total volulme for IV preparation vial 12mL)
formulations.dispensing_description: Give first dose of artesunate IV injection over 3-4 minutes, and refer to the hospital. If you are unable to refer for hospitalization, repeat dose after 12 hrs and daily until the child can take orally. Give full dose of oral antimalarial as soon as the child is able to take orally.

formulations.injection_instructions:
"NOTE: Injectable 60mg artesunate has two-step dilutions.

bicarbonate and shaken vigorously 2–3 minutes till the solution becomes clear.
Step 2: For IV infusion (3–4 minutes), add 5 mL of 5% dextrose or normal

If you are unable to refer for hospitalization, repeat dose after 12 hrs and daily until the child can take orally. Give full dose of oral antimalarial as soon as the child is able to take orally.

1742.label: Quinine IM
1742.description:
2nd line Anti-malarial treatment for severe malaria
Weight based loading dose: 20 mg/Kg

formulations.injection_instructions: No dilution needed.
formulations.dispensing_description: Provide intramuscular injection in two divided doses on the antero-lateral thigh.

1839.label: Refer for specialized outpatient investigation: neck mass
1839.description:
TB, tumor, or other complicated infection must be investigated.

Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigation. 

If child is well appearing / stable, consider withholding antibiotics before TB investigation.

If child unwell, semi-urgent referral my be warranted.

1841.label: Balanitis symptomatic care
1841.description:
As long as symptoms persist, advise patient sitz bath 2-3 times per day:

Sitz bath: Soaking of the penis in clean, warm water containing a weak salt solution for 10-15 min

1842.label: Vulvovaginitis care
1842.description:
-	Advice to avoid local irritations by wearing loose cotton underwear and by avoiding tight jeans, local irritans like perfumed soaps, excessing use of soap 
-	Vinegar Sitz baths: add 1-2 spoons of white vinegar to hand warm water and soak for 10-15 min., rinse and pat dry 
-	Cold compresses: fill a bowl with cold water or with ice and water, submerge a clean towel or washcloth into the bowl and then wring it out. Apply for 10 min, pat dry 
-	Consider deworming with Mebendazole (therapeutic) if presence of anal and/or nighttime itch

1720.label: Azithromycin po (STI)
1720.description: Antibiotic: Azithromycin sexual transmitted infection dosage, 1g/dose

formulations.dispensing_description: Can be given on empty or full stomach.
Can be given on empty or full stomach

1719.label: Ceftriaxone IM (STI)
1719.description:
Antibiotic:  Ceftriaxone IM for Sexually transmitted infection
Dosage 1g/dose/day

formulations.injection_instructions:
"Step 1: The powder for injection should be diluted with 0.9ml sterile water for injection
 Step 2: Add water for injection slowly and then shake vigorously until evenly mixed. The total volume will be approximately 1ml."
formulations.dispensing_description: Administer by deep IM route

1721.label: Metronidazole po (STI)
1721.description: Antibiotic: Metronidazole, dosage for sexual transmitted disease,  400mg/dose twice a day

formulations.dispensing_description: Give with food to minimize stomach upset.

1843.label: Safe sex counselling
1843.description:
-	Provide health education on safe sex
-	Discuss importance of using condoms to prevent acquisition of STIs, HIV, and unwanted pregnancies. 
-	Provide condoms if available

1844.label: Partner management
1844.description: Advise the partner or partners to visit health facility for treatment (if not possible, provide treatment for the partner(s)

1845.label: Ask for sexual abuse (only if resources are available to help)
1845.description: If resources are available to help victims of sexual abuse, ask if the patient was a victim of sexual abuse. If they were, be empathetic and supportive, refer the child to the appropriate organization that manages sexual abuse (Social welfare, health and police; social services and child protection).

1800.label: Fluconazole po (vaginal candidiasis)
1800.description:
2nd line antifungal for vaginal candidiasis
Age 8-14 years: 150mg

Give with or without food

1722.label: Doxycycline (STI)
1722.description:
Antibiotic: Doxycycline for sexual transmitted infection
100mg/dose twice a day

formulations.dispensing_description: Give with food to reduce stomach upset.

1692.label: Acyclovir po (HSV)
1692.description: Antiviral for HSV: dosage based on weight: 80mg/kg/day; daily maximum dose 1200mg.

formulations.dispensing_description: Take with or without food 3 times a day
Take with or without food 3 times a day

3770.label: Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) by naso-gastric tube
3770.description: ORS by naso-gastric tube in cases of Severe dehydration

formulations.dispensing_description:
- Dilute 1 sachet of ORS in one liter of clean water. 
- In the clinic give the recommended amount of ORS over 6-hour period (120ml/Kg/6 hours = 20ml/kg/hour).
- If there is repeated vomiting or increasing abdominal distension, give the fluid more slowly.
- If hydration status is not improving after 3 hour, send the patient for IV therapy.
- After 6 hours, re-assess for dehydration

2087.label: Switch oral antibiotics or antimalarials to IM antibiotics or antimalarials

3767.label: IV fluid for Severe Dehydration
3767.description:
Start IV fluid immediately. If the patient can drink, give ORS (5ml/Kg/hour) by mouth while the drip is set up.
Give 100ml/kg Ringer's Lactate Solution (or, if not available, normal saline) divided as follows:

- Infants (under 12 months): First give 30ml/kg in 1 hour*, and then give 70 ml/kg over 5 hours
- Older (12 months or older): First give 30ml/kg in 30 minutes*, and then give 70 ml/kg over 2.5 hours
*Repeat once if radial pulse is very weak or not detectable

- Reassess the patient every 1-2 hours. If hydration status is not improving, give the IV drip more rapidly.
- Also give ORS (about 5ml/kg/hour) as soon as the patient can drink: usually after 3-4 hours (infants) or 1-2 hours for children/adolescents.
- Reassess an infant after 6 hours and older patient after 3 hours.

formulations.dispensing_description:
For Infants - dissolve tablet in a small amount of expressed breast milk, ORS or clean water in a cup.
Older children - tablets can be chewed or dissolved in a small amount of water.
Tablets can be chewed or dissolved in a small amount of water.

3765.label: Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) in the clinic: WHO Treatment Plan B
3765.description: Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) for the treatment of some dehydration (WHO Treatment Plan B) in the clinic

formulations.dispensing_description:
- Dilute 1 sachet of ORS in one liter of clean water. 
- In the clinic give the recommended amount of ORS over a 4-hour period (75ml/Kg).
- If the child wants more ORS than shown, give more.
- For infants under 6 months who are not breastfed, also give 100-200ml clean water during this period if you use standard ORS. This is not needed if you use new low osmolarity ORS

Show the mother how to give ORS solution:
- Give frequent small sips form a cup
- If the child vomits, wait 10 min, then continue but more slowly
- Continue breastfeeding whenever the child wants.

AFTER 4 HOURS:
- Reassess the child and classify the child for dehydration
- Select the appropriate plan to continue treatment
- Begin feeding the child in clinic

IF THE MOTHER MUST LEAVE BEFORE COMPLETING THE TREATMENT:
- Show her how to prepare ORS solution at home
- Show her how much ORS to give to finish 4-hour treatment at home.
Giver her enough ORS packets to complete rehydration.

3424.label: Refer for inpatient management
3424.description: Refer with caretaker for inpatient management at a health centre or hospital with sufficient capacity to manage the illness of the patient. If referral is not possible, manage the child as described in the national guidelines or WHO Pocket Book for hospital care for children.

1862.label: Feeding counselling (6m-9m)
1862.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give thick porridge or well mashed foods, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
- Start by giving 2 to 3 tablespoons of food. Gradually increase to 1/2 cups (1 cup = 250 ml). Give 2 to 3 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks each day between meals when the child seems hungry.

1863.label: Feeding counselling (9-12m)
1863.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 1/2 cup at each meal(1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals. The child will eat if hungry.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

1864.label: Feeding counselling (1-2y)
1864.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants.
- Also give a variety of mashed or finely chopped family food, including animal source foods and vitamin A-rich fruits and vegetables.
-Give 3/4 cup at each meal (1 cup = 250 ml).
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- Continue to feed your child slowly, patiently. Encourage - but do not force - your child to eat.
- For snacks, give small chewable items that the child can hold. Let your child try to eat the snack, but provide help if needed.

1865.label: Feeding counselling (>=2y)
1865.description:
- Give a variety of family foods to your child, including animal source foods and vitamin rich fruits and vegetables.
- Give at least 1 full cup (250 ml) at each meal.
- Give 3 to 4 meals each day.
- Offer 1 or 2 snacks between meals.
- If your child refuses a new food, offer "tastes" several times. Show that you like the food.
Be patient.
- Talk with your child during a meal, and keep eye contact.

2209.label: Refer
2209.description: Refer to a health facility with capacity to provide appropriate care. An appointment can be made or care can be sought when possible/feasible. Write a referral note for the mother to take to the hospital.

1816.label: Refer for specialized outpatient investigations: TB assessment
1816.description:
- Children with moderate to severe malnutrition, significant hemoptysis, significant loss of weight, cough or fever >=2 weeks, known close TB contact in past 12 months with respiratory complaints, should be evaluated for TB infection
-	Refer for TB assessment or if TB assessment performed at this health facility, follow in-house protocol. 
-	If patient is stable, do not give antibiotics until specimen collection is completed

3435.label: Tuberculosis screening at health facility
3435.description: Proceed with Tuberculosis screening as defined by your health facility protocols.

1813.label: Refer for specialized outpatient investigations: hemoptysis
1813.description: The child is coughing up blood, this merits further investigation as it may be a sign of tuberculosis, lung cancer, or of a foreign body in the airway.

formulations.injection_instructions: 2.4 MIU should be dissolved in 5 ml of water for injection. It is reconstituted by adding sterile water slowly and shake the vial until it is well mixed
formulations.dispensing_description: Inject 2.5mL (1.2 MIU) in each buttocks for a total of 5mL (2.4 MIU)IM; Powder for injection; 	1.44g (2.4 million IU) in 5ml vial;

1806.label: Ibuprofen po
1806.description:
Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAID)
Dosage based on Weight  : 30mg/kg (15-30mg/kg/day)

formulations.dispensing_description: Give with food or milk
Give with food or milk

1849.label: Consider repeating pregnancy test in 2 weeks

1850.label: Pregnancy counselling
1850.description:
-	Visit the health centre at least 4 times during the pregnancy, even without problems. Additional visits if there is any concern about mother and/or baby 
-	Eat more and healthier foods (incl. more fruits, vegetables, beans, pasteurized cheese and milk)
-	Avoid lifting heavy objects, rest when you can 
-	Take iron tablets as explained by the health worker
-	Sleep under a bednet treated with insecticide 
-	Do not take medication unless prescribed at the health centre 
-	Do not drink alcohol or smoke
-	Use a condom correctly in every sexual relation to prevent STI or HIV, if you or the companion are at risk of infection 
-	Go immediately to hospital if: vaginal bleeding, convulsions, severe headache with blurred vision, fever and too weak to go out of bed, severe abdominal pain, fast/difficult breathing (danger signs)
-	Go to health centre if water breaks, if painful contractions every 20 min. or less and if presence of bloody sticky discharge (signs of labour)

1851.label: Refer or advise to seek obstetric clinic

4068.label: Continue antibiotic prescription as previously prescribed
4068.description:
For all follow-up consultations, if an antibiotic prescription was previously prescribed advise the patient to continue taking the prescribed antibiotic for the intended duration, even if there is an improvement in the symptoms.

If the patient now has a severe illness and needs to be referred, the IV/IM drugs will replace the past drugs.

1853.label: Manual detorsion of testicules
1853.description:
-	Manual detorsion is always from the medial to the lateral side (“opening a book”) 
-	May need to rotate 2-3 times for complete detorsion 
-	If the manoeuvre is successful, the patient feels a dramatic resolution of pain 
-	Refer after manual detorsion

1856.label: Refer for specialized outpatient management: Surgical
1856.description:
Refer to referral/district hospital or health center for surgical management. 

If distal forearm fracture in child under 5 years old, referral may not be needed.

If clavicular fracture:
Put a broad arm sling to support the limb for 2 weeks and:
-        Encourage the child to use hand and fingers
-        Avoid sports for 6 weeks especially contact sports
-        A lump at the fracture site is normal and may take about a year to disappear. In older children, a small bump may remain 

Advise to return to clinic if:
-        There is pain at the site of fracture after 6 weeks
-        There is a persistent tingling or altered sensation in the arm or hand

4597.label: Headache guidance
4597.description:
- Check vision - consider trial of glasses
- Suggest neck massage
- Refer if headache persists more than 2 weeks
- If on ARV drugs, this may be a side effect, refer child to CTC

REF: IMAI 2009

2021.label: Constipation counselling
2021.description:
"-    The goal is achieving one, soft, easy to pass bowel action per day (exception: breastfed babies who are otherwise well may defecate infrequently (several times a day to one a week)  
-     Treatment is usually required for several months:
-      Encourage to eat fruits/vegetables
-      Eating only ugali or rice may worsen constipation, diversify types of food if possible
-      Avoid rectal medication or manipulation 

If constipation counselling is not sufficient for children >= 3 years a trial of bisacodyl 5mg tablets once daily may help."

1743.label: Iron po
1743.description:
Iron supplementation for anemia
Weight	based dosage: 3mg/Kg of iron (3-6mg/Kg); daily max dose 200mg

formulations.dispensing_description: For optimal absorption, it should be taken between meals with water or juice (milk reduces absorption).
For optimal absorption, it should be taken between meals with water or juice (milk reduces absorption).

2080.label: No referral. Return for follow up in 14 days
2080.description:
No referral is needed, but follow up in 14 days is warranted

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child earlier if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever
- After 7 days: No improvement of symptoms (some symptoms such as oral aphtous ulcers, oral candidiasis, some skin lesions/rashes may take more than 7 days to improve)
- Cough duration more than 2 weeks
- Neck mass persisting more than 4 weeks

*Consider earlier scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

3414.label: Mild/moderate anemia counseling
3414.description:
Anemia is caused by a number of diseases including malnutrition, hookworm and whipworm infections, malaria, sickle cell disease and many others.

Prescribe deworming medication if the child did not receive any in the past 6 months. Assess nutrition and be vigilant for any signs of malaria. If sickle cell testing is possible refer for testing.

3782.label: Iron supplementation 2 weeks after febrile illness
3782.description: If the child has a febrile illness it is recommended to only start oral iron treatment 14 days after the end of the febrile illness.

4051.label: Consider outpatient referral if already on iron treatment for more than two month
4051.description: If the patient is already on iron treatment for more than two months, or has received multiple diagnoses of anemia, consider referral for outpatient investigation of sickle cell disease.

4590.label: Counsel the caregiver to continue providing half strength gential violet for a total of 7 days

1822.label: Feeding conseling (<6 months)
1822.description:
- Breastfeed as often as your child wants. Look for signs of hunger, such as beginning to fuss, sucking fingers, or moving lips.
- Breastfeed day and night whenever your baby wants, at least 8 times in 24 hours. Frequent feeding produces more milk.
- Do not give other foods or fluids. Breast milk is all your baby needs.

1798.label: Vitamin A  po (retinol) for 6 to 12 months of age

formulations.dispensing_description: Do not give if the child is less than 6 months, or is already on RUTF, or received vit A within the past month.
Do not give if the child is less than 6 months, or is already on RUTF, or received vit A within the past month.

1799.description:

4058.label: Refer for outpatient evaluation: HIV care and treatment centre

formulations.dispensing_description:
Give with or without food. Tablets may be chewed, swallowed whole, or crushed and mixed with food.
Repeat single dose (100mg) after 14 days.

Give with or without food.
Repeat single dose (100mg) after 14 days.

1767.label: Albendazole (therapeutic) po  for 1-2 years
1767.description:
Anti-helminthics for oxyuriasis 
Dosage based on Age; for	1-2 years: 200mg

formulations.dispensing_description:
Give with high-fat meal.
Tablets may be crushed or chewed, then swallowed with a drink of water.
Repeat single dose (200mg orally) after 14 days

1768.label: Albendazole (therapeutic) po for >= 2 to 14 years
1768.description:
Anti-helminthics for oxyuriasis
Dosage based on Age; for 2-14 years: 400mg

formulations.dispensing_description: Repeat single dose (400mg orally) after 14 days

2025.label: Refer for specialized outpatient consultation: Orthopedics
2025.description: Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigations and management by health care workers with advanced capacity to manage chronic limp, or chronic joint pain, or severe deep tissue injury, or suspected/confirmed fracture.

1819.label: Amoxicillin / clavulanic acid (IV)
1819.description:
ANTIBIOTIC for osteomyelitis/septic arhtritis
Weight based dosage based on Amoxicillin: 100mg/kg/day; split in 2 doses 12 hours apart (min 80mg/kg/day; max 100mg/kg/day)

formulations.injection_instructions: Vials of 500 mg/100 mg are diluted with 10 ml of water for injections. The volume after reconstitution is approximately  10 ml.
formulations.dispensing_description: Administer as an infusion over 30-40 minutes.

2026.label: Wound care
2026.description:
Technique

– Settle the patient comfortably in an area with good lighting and ensure all the necessary material is prepared.
– Explain the procedure to the patient and ensure his co-operation.
– If the patient is a young child, arrange to have an assistant hold the child if necessary.
Initial cleaning

– Wear suitable clothing: sterile gloves for all wounds and a gown and protective glasses if there is a risk of projection from a bleeding wound.
– Start by washing the wound, prolong the cleaning if the wound is particularly soiled. Use ordinary soap or 7.5% povidone iodine scrub solution and water and rinse.
– If necessary use a sterile brush. Cleaning with running water is preferable to cleaning by immersion.
– If the wound is infected and the patient has general signs of infection (fever, chills, changes in the overall condition) systemic antibiotic therapy may be required. Administer antibiotics at least one hour prior to starting care.
Exploration

– Wash hands and put on sterile gloves.
– Disinfect the wound and surrounding area with 10% povidone iodine.
– Cover the wound with a fenestrated sterile towel.
– Local anaesthetic: infiltrate 1% lidocaine into the edges of the wound and wait at least 2 minutes for the anaesthetic to take effect.
– Proceed carefully from the superficial to the deepest parts of the wound to explore the extent of the wound, if necessary, aided by an assistant.
– Consider the anatomical location of the wound and look for injury to any underlying structures (the clinical examination of a limb must include evaluation of sensitivity and motor functioning, as well as that of tendons in order to orient surgical exploration):
• a wound that communicates with a fracture is an open fracture,
• a wound close to a joint may be a joint wound,
• a wound on the hands or feet may affect the nerves and/or tendons.
– Look for and remove any foreign bodies.
– In the event of significant pain or bleeding, the exploration must be completed in an operating room.
Wound excision

– The goal of the excision is to remove non-viable tissue, which favours the proliferation of bacteria and infection.
– The wound may require little or no excision if it is clean. The excision is more extensive if the wound is bruised, irregular or extensive.
– Limit excision of the skin around the wound, particularly in facial wounds.
– Sub-cutaneous fat and tissue of doubtful viability should be generously excised in order to leave only well vascularised tissue.

REF: MSF Clinical Guidelines

2027.label: Tetanus vaccine if incomplete
2027.description:
Provide tetanus vaccination if: 
- < 3 vaccines or unknown vaccination history, or 
- last vaccine >10 years ago (>5 years if deep or dirty wound)

2082.label: Refer for specialized outpatient consultation: Rabies
2082.description: Refer to referral/district hospital for specialized outpatient investigations and management of potential rabies exposure

2083.label: Refer for urgent specialized outpatient management: Wound
2083.description:
Refer to referral/district hospital or referral health centre for outpatient management of wound (+/- sutures)
Advise patient / caregiver that they must complete referral within 24 hrs (clean wound) or 6hrs (dirty wound) for sutures

2040.label: Dislocation management
2040.description:
Reduction attempts of dislocation can result in significant pain, and rarely can result in fractures, rotator cuff injuries, and/or axillary artery or nerve injury.

Only perform reduction maneuvers if you are trained in doing so.

2034.label: Clavicular fracture management
2034.description:
Put a broad arm sling to support the limb for 2 weeks and:
-        Encourage the child to use hand and fingers
-        Avoid sports for 6 weeks especially contact sports
-        A lump at the fracture site is normal and may take about a year to disappear. In older children, a small bump may remain 

Refer if: 
-        Open fracture
-        Skin at risk over fracture
-        Neurovascular injury (problem with sensation, movement, vascularisation of the limb) 
-        Severe comminuted or shortened bone
-        Displaced lateral or medial third of the bone

Advise to return to clinic if:
-        There is pain at the site of fracture after 6 weeks
-        There is a persistent tingling or altered sensation in the arm or hand

1772.label: Mupirocin cream 2%
1772.description: Anti-infective skin cream for burns and impetigo

formulations.dispensing_description: Apply a small amount of the cream to the affected area twice daily.

4052.label: Major burn care
4052.description:
- Run the burn area under cool water for 20-30 minutes
- Cover the wound with a clean cloth or sterile gauze after application of mupirocin cream or silver sulfadiazine cream

REF: Tanzania Standard Treatment Guidelines 2019 and South African Burn Society management guidelines

2043.label: Burn care
2043.description:
- Run the burn area under cool water for 20-30 minutes
-	If skin is intact, clean with antiseptic solution (povidone iodine) gently without breaking the skin.
-	If skin is not intact, debride the burn carefully.
-	If Mupirocin or Silver sulfadiazine not available advise mother to apply honey to the affected areas every 12 hours
-	Advise mother to return to the health facility to clean and dress the wound  every 24 to 48 hours
REF: Tanzania Standard Treatment Guidelines 2019 and South African Burn Society management guidelines

2045.label: Return every 24-48 hours to clean and dress wound

2046.label: Consider child abuse if burn from object (Refer to social worker)

2047.label: Head injury guidance
2047.description:
The child may have a headache after head injury. 
Give them paracetamol every six hours if needed to relieve the pain
If the child develops cognitive fatigue (problems concentrating, difficulties with memory, more anxious, mood swings, changed sleep patterns, slowness when thinking), the child needs a complete rest for 24-48hrs (no watching TV or playing on mobile electronic devices).
Introduce gradually physical exercise (walking, cycling)
Avoid second trauma (preventing falls) 

Return to clinic if during the child's recovery (especially during the next 48hrs), he/she has any of the following:
- severe/persistent headache that is not relieved by paracetamol
- Frequent vomiting at home 
- Bleeding or discharge from the ear or nose
- A fit or convulsion 
- Difficulty in waking up or staying awake 

REF: Adapted from the Royal Children's Hospital Emergency, Neurosurgery and Neuropsychology departments' Head Injury fact sheets, 2018

3529.label: 4 hour surveillance for head injury
3529.description:
Keep the child for surveillance for 4 hours to see the progression of symptoms. If symptoms improve, the child may be okay to return home with head injury guidance. 

If symptoms worsen, referral to a referral/district hospital may be needed.

3532.label: Control bleeding
3532.description:
If major bleeding use simple dressings with direct pressure to control the bleeding.

In patients with major limb trauma use a tourniquet (a tight bandage/wrap that is placed proximal to the site of trauma (closer to the body) if direct pressure has failed to control life‑threatening bleeding.
(REF: NICE guidelines)

3533.label: Stabilize neck
3533.description:
If neck trauma or possible cervical spine injury stabilize neck, and keep the child lying on the back.
Tape the child's forehead and chin to the sides of a firm board to secure this position.
Prevent the neck from moving by supporting the child's head (e.g. using litre bags of IV fluid on each side).
If the child is vomiting, turn on the side, keeping the head in line with the body.

medias.label: Stabilize neck (WHO Pocket Book of Hospital care for children)

3530.label: Oxygen therapy
3530.description:
Give oxygen through nasal prongs or a nasal catheter. 

Start oxygen flow rate at:
0.5 – 1L/min for neonates
1-2 L/min for infants
2-4 L/min for older children
>4 L/min if via face mask

2049.label: Uncomplicated poisoning guidance
2049.description:
Explain to the caretaker/patient that the ingestion of an unknown product/medication or toxic product can result in a severe disease. While the child is not presenting any severe symptoms now, they may appear at a later time.

Tell the caretaker to pay close attention to the child. He/she must return to the clinic if the patient presents any of the following signs/symptoms:
- Agitation
- Confusion
- Dizziness
- Headache
- Convulsions
- Altered consciousness

2051.label: Abscess care
2051.description:
Incision:
– Hold the scalpel between the thumb and middle finger of the dominant hand, the index finger presses on the handle. Hold the abscess between the thumb and index finger of the other hand. The scalpel blade should be perpendicular to the skin.
– The incision is made in a single stroke along the long axis of the abscess. The incision must be long enough for a finger to be inserted.
– Be cautious when excising an abscess located over a blood vessel (carotid, axillary, humeral, femoral, popliteal).

Digital exploration:
– Explore the cavity with the index finger, breaking down all loculi (a single cavity should remain), evacuate the pus and explore to the edges of the cavity.
– The exploration also allows an assessment of the extent of the abscess, the depth, and location with respect to underlying structures (arterial pulsation) or any possible contact with underlying bone. In this last case, seek surgical advice.

Washing:
Abundant washing of the cavity using a syringe filled with antiseptic solution.

Drainage:
Insert a drain (or, failing that a gauze wick) into the base of the cavity. If possible, fix it to the edge of the incision with a single suture. The drain is withdrawn progressively and then, after 3 to 5 days removed completely.

REF MSF Clinical Guidelines

2053.label: Refer for evaluation for parenteral antibiotic TT

3413.label: No referral: Follow up in 7 days
3413.description:
No referral is needed, but follow up in 7 days is warranted

Advise the caretaker to bring back the child earlier if the child presents: 
- At any time: Respiratory distress, worsening of difficulty in breathing, is not able to drink or breastfeed, convulsions, new fever, new episode of blood in stool, if the child becomes unconscious, lethargic, or becomes sicker
- After 3 days: Persisting fever

*Consider earlier scheduled follow-up or referral if the child is malnourished, has uncontrolled HIV, or other severe comorbidities.

2054.label: Skin hygiene precautions
2054.description:
-	Avoid scratching. Cut nails short
-	Wash hands frequently. 
-	Wash lesions with soap and water.
-      Keep lesions covered with gauze if possible

2060.label: Eczema guidance
2060.description:
-	Avoid triggers such as abrasive and aggressive soaps
-	Reduce the number and duration of bathing
-	Apply hydrating cream after bathing (Vaseline)

2061.label: Pityriasis versicolor guidance
2061.description:
-	Lesions worsen on heat and humid conditions
-	 Avoid oily lotions
-	Hypopigmentation may persist after successful treatment. Advise patient that the skin may only return to normal after a couple of months.
